com.milk.objed
Interface Editor

All Known Subinterfaces:
FieldsEditor, ValueEditor
All Known Implementing Classes:
BaseEditor, BaseFieldsEditor, BaseWrappedValueEditor, DirectValueEditor, FieldValueEditor, MethodValueEditor
public interface Editor

This interface is mostly just to mark objects which know how to perform edits on another object but does have a couple of actual method definitions. It implies no particular human interface. In order to actually accomplish human editing, one must hand Editor objects to some user-interface or other (for example, the classes in com.milk.objed.gui).

Author:
Dan Bornstein, danfuzz@milk.com
, Copyright 1999 Dan Bornstein, all rights reserved.

Method Detail

addListener

public void addListener(java.util.EventListener listener)
Add a listener to this object. If the listener is in fact an EditorListener then it will get all the EditorEvents that get generated for this object. Subclasses may want to define other event classes that get generated, of course.

Parameters:
listener - the listener to add

removeListener

public void removeListener(java.util.EventListener listener)
Remove a listener from this object that was previously added with addListener().

Parameters:
listener - the listener to remove

getLabel

public java.lang.String getLabel()
Get a short human-oriented label/description for the object this editor is editing. The description should be suitable as a label next to this editor, and shouldn't ever change during the lifetime of this editor.

Returns:
the label

getDescription

public java.lang.String getDescription()
Get a full human-oriented description for the object this editor is editing. The description should be suitable for tip-text or the like. It's okay for the description to change, and if it does, a descriptionChanged event will be sent to any registered listeners.

Returns:
the full description

isMutable

public boolean isMutable()
Return true if this editor is mutable. That is, if this method returns true, then edits can actually happen on this object. If false, this object is for display only. If the mutability of this object changes, a mutabilityChanged event will be sent to any registered listeners.

Returns:
true if this editor is mutable

update

public void update()
Ask this editor to update its internal state. This is useful if the end value(s) that the editor manipulates is (are) unable to notify the editor directly when they change. For many editors, this in fact does nothing, for some it merely resends the request to sub-editors, and for some it actually does some sort of value update.
